ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

WITHDRAWAL OF NEW ZEALAND FORCES


    1. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (a) what are the reasons for the withdrawal of New Zealand forces from Singapore; and (b) what impact it will have on our defence capability.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Sir, I am answering on behalf of the First Deputy Prime Minister.

    Sir, let me preface my answer with a short history of the contribution of the New Zealand Forces to the security of South East Asia in the past three decades.

    New Zealand Forces stationed in Singapore today comprise the First Royal New Zealand Infantry Regiment, the Headquarters of the New Zealand Forces in South East Asia and a small detachment of helicopters.

    Since 1955, 32 years ago, New Zealand Forces have been deployed in Malaysia, then Malaya, where they fought communist insurgents and later formed part of the Commonwealth Forces during the Indonesian Confrontation between 1964 and 1966. In 1969 the 1st Battalion, Royal New Zealand Infantry Regiment, moved to Singapore.

    At a time when Singapore and Malaysia were newly independent and when the British announced their withdrawal, the continued stationing of New Zealand Forces was a significant show of support and an assuring gesture to countries in the region. It afforded these countries the lead time to develop economically and politically and to strengthen their own defence capabilities.

    Coming now to the question proper, New Zealand's intention to withdraw its forces from South East Asia is the result of the New Zealand Government defence policy review which recommended concentrating their defence forces and capabilities on New Zealand's immediate environment, in particular the South Pacific region. Moreover, the South East

Column: 1148

Asian countries today have not only successfully tackled the communist threat and confrontation but have gone on to develop their own defence capabilities.

    New Zealand's decision to withdraw its forces from Singapore was taken after mutual consultations between New Zealand and Singapore and the other parties of the Five Power Defence Arrangement.

    The Government of New Zealand has expressed its wish to remain an active member of the Five Power Defence Arrangement. It is also the intention of the New Zealand Government to continue its participation in joint exercises and to cooperate in existing and new areas of bilateral relationship within the framework of the Five Power Defence Arrangement.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, can I ask the Minister what impact the withdrawal of the New Zealand Forces will have on ASEAN military cooperation, especially cooperation with our neighbours.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the cooperation between the Asean countries will continue.

CHANGES IN POLITICAL LEADERSHIP OF VIETNAM
(Effect on Cambodian issue)


    2. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, with the recent changes in the political leadership of Vietnam, whether (i) the possibility of the Cambodian issue being resolved has improved and (ii) tension in the region has ameliorated with a Vietnam that is focussing its attention on economic reforms.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Sir, the top three Politburo members of the Communist Party of Vietnam retired in December 1986, and in mid-February 1987 there was a ministerial reshuffle. Since the leadership changes, there has been no hard evidence of Vietnam's sincerity in wanting to resolve the Cambodian problem. It has merely repeated pledges to withdraw all Vietnamese troops from Cambodia by 1990 or

Column: 1149

earlier. Since these pledges of withdrawal are predicated on Vietnam achieving its hegemonistic objectives in Cambodia, they do not offer hope for a solution. Vietnam is not prepared to hold direct discussions with the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea, the party directly affected by Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia.

    Whilst the leadership changes and the streamlining of several economic ministries point to a concentration on economic reconstruction of the country, the changes have also promoted several personalities who have been closely associated with the invasion and occupation of Cambodia. These changes do not augur well for any compromise on Cambodia.

    The recent spate of Vietnamese initiated moves to promote a dialogue on the Cambodian problem are clearly aimed at giving the misleading impression that there is some movement and a solution is in sight.

    Notwithstanding this, Vietnam's preoccupation with economic problems, its nervousness at the improvement in Sino-Soviet relations and its continued international isolation might well lead to a more realistic attitude on Cambodia. We will therefore have to wait for more concrete moves on Vietnam's part.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether this change of leadership in Vietnam is in fact a change of tack that they have moved from a military expansion scheme to an economic expansion scheme where they can have a better hold on the surrounding countries and then by proxy the Soviet Union could expand its sphere of influence in this region.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I do not think that is the intention. The economy is in such a bad situation that it will require a lot of convincing for anybody to believe that Vietnam can project its power, its influence, as a result of being a strong economy. I think the primary aim of these changes is to mend the internal economy of Vietnam.

Column: 1150



     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Can I ask the Minister in view of the changes in the political leadership whether there is prospect for improved relations between Singapore and Vietnam?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, I think it is a bit too early to say what the prospects are. If, as I said, the leadership changes result in some concrete moves in finding a solution to the Cambodian problem, obviously the stage will be set for better relations between Singapore and Vietnam.

AYER RAJAH ROAD/CLEMENTI ROAD/PASIR PANJANG ROAD/COMMONWEALTH AVENUE WEST
(Progress of road works)


    3. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will report on the progress of the road works that run concurrently at (i) Ayer Rajah Road, (ii) Clementi Road, (iii) Pasir Panjang Road and (iv) Commonwealth Avenue West; and (b) whether pedestrian overhead bridges will be built and safety measures taken to minimize accidents along these new expressways.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, the PWD is upgrading Ayer Rajah Road and Upper Ayer Rajah Road to form part of the Ayer Rajah Expressway. Ayer Rajah Road extends from Alexandra Road to Clementi Road. The PWD expects to complete this stretch of road by the end of 1987. The upgrading of the stretch of Upper Ayer Road from Clementi Road to Jurong Town Hall Road will be completed by the first quarter of 1988.

    Sir, the widening of Clementi Road from Ayer Rajah Road to West Coast Highway is about 60% completed. The project is scheduled to be completed by September 1987.

    The widening of Pasir Panjang Road was completed on 11th March 1987.

    The widening of Commonwealth Avenue West between Jalan Lempeng and Jurong East Street 11 started on the 16th

Column: 1151

February 1987 and will be completed by November 1987.

    Of the four roads mentioned, only Ayer Rajah Road will be upgraded to an expressway. The others are major arterial roads. The following safety measures have been taken to minimize accidents along this expressway:

    (1) Provision of 13 pedestrian overhead bridges and an underpass for pedestrian safety.

    (2) Installation of vehicular impact guardrails along the sides of the expressway to prevent vehicles from running off the expressway; and

    (3) Provision of prominent lane markings and adequate directional road signs to guide motorists.

HDB RENTAL BLOCKS
(Demolition and Redevelopment)


    4. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the progress of the programme to demolish Housing and Development Board rental apartments with high vacancies; (b) what are the problems encountered; and (c) when will the land recovered under this programme be developed and what will be the nature of the proposed development.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, the exercise to relocate tenants in rental blocks commenced in November 1986. Tenants in 369 blocks have been notified of the relocation exercise. The 369 blocks consist of 40,168 units, of which 25,059 are occupied.

    As at 11th March 1987, a total of 5,835 affected tenants have registered to purchase home ownership flats whereas 6,064 tenants have registered to rent another flat. Of the 11,899 cases registered, 3,467 tenants have already been allocated alternative flats, out of which 1,043 in sold flats and 2,424 in rental flats.

    Sir, the blocks will be demolished progressively as and when all tenants in the blocks have been rehoused.

    Sir, at present the HDB has not experienced any major problems in the relocation exercise as there are sufficient rental and home ownership flats to meet the demand from tenants affected by the exercise.

    When the land recovered under this programme reaches a sizeable parcel, it will be redeveloped.

    The general objective of the redevelopment, Sir, is to upgrade the old estates to approximate current standards. The land could be used to build better flats or other facilities for the old estates.

PUBLIC TELEPHONES ALONG EXPRESSWAYS
(Conversion into emergency telephones)


    6. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development whether all the public telephones along expressways have been removed for the sake of road safety and whether they will be substituted by hot lines linking directly to the Police and the Fire Brigade for emergency use.

Column: 1153



     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, emergency telephones are a necessity along expressways for motorists in distress to seek assistance. It is also a standard provision along such roads in the developed countries.

    In Singapore, public telephones were installed for motorists to use as emergency telephones. But motorists are using them for personal and business calls. On the average, 66 calls per day are made from each telephone. Vehicles stopping along the expressways pose a hazard to other road users. In the first six months of 1986, there were nine cases of serious accidents attributable to the use of public telephones along expressways.

    The Public Works Department together with the Police and Telecoms is looking into the conversion of these public telephones to emergency telephones which only allow calls for help to the Police, Fire Service and towing companies.

COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE "TEH CHEANG WAN AFFAIR"
(Statement by the Second Minister for Law)


     Prof. S. Jayakumar: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, Members will recall that at our sitting on 4th March, the Member for Potong Pasir asked the Prime Minister "whether he will call a public inquiry to get to the bottom of (what he termed) the Teh Cheang Wan affair and to make recommendations to prevent further corruption at high places." The Prime Minister said that the Government is ready to have a public inquiry into any matter of public interest so that there can be no question of any cover-up. The Prime Minister repeatedly asked the Member to spell out the terms of reference. It was only after the lunch adjournment that the Member read out his proposed terms, although he said that he had it all the time since that morning.

    The Prime Minister pointed out that the terms were ambiguous and suggested that the Member refine them. Nevertheless, the Prime Minister said he was prepared to accept the draft as it was and to gazette it because he would not stop any inquiry. In

Column: 1154

reply, the Member insisted that "as far as the substance of this reference goes, (that is, the reference of the inquiry that he wanted) it stays." The Member also requested that there should be three commissioners instead of one. In response to the Prime Minister's question whether he would lead evidence on the terms requested by him, he said:

    '... not only I will lead in evidence but I have certainly people who are willing to assist me in that area.'

    And this was noted by the Prime Minister when he said:

    '... as he said he would lead evidence and he will bring people to bring evidence. So be it.'

    The Member's final words on the terms were:

    'I wish to have these terms of reference written out in a form that is accepted under the Inquiry Commissions Act.'

    In deference to the Member's stated desire to recast his terms in an acceptable form, the Government waited for his redraft. On the morning of 23rd March, I asked the Member whether he had a redraft or if his terms read out in the House on 4th March were final. He asked for time, and at about 6.00 pm that day he handed me his revised terms of reference.

    I now wish to inform the House that the President has appointed a Commission of Inquiry consisting of three members as proposed by the Member. The Chairman of the Commission will be Judicial Commissioner, Mr Chan Sek Keong, and the other two members will be Mr Robert Iau Kuo Kwong and Mr Thai Chee Ken. The full text of the instrument of appointment signed by the President will be gazetted soon and is now circulated for the information of hon. Members. I shall request the Clerk to kindly distribute the said instrument. [Copies of instrument distributed to hon. Members].

    Sir, this instrument reproduces the revised terms of reference submitted by the Member for Potong Pasir in their entirety as terms of reference No.(2) and No.(3). The instrument also records the fact that the Member had undertaken to lead in evidence (the words used by him) relating to those said terms.

    If I may turn to another matter, Sir. At our sitting of 4th March, the Member made

Column: 1155

several references which implied that the CPIB had been less than thorough in their investigation of the case. For example, he asked whether, now that the Minister has died, everything will be closed and covered up. He said that there was "evidence that strange goings-on have taken place. This is indeed very, very strange. So I think there is need for an inquiry into that area." Then referring to a core contractor willing to give a bribe, he said:

    'It is no small sum. There must be certainly something behind that. If we dig deep enough, we will find the evidence.'

    In other words, he casts a doubt over the thoroughness and effectiveness of CPIB's investigations that they did not dig deep enough.

    The Government had expected the Member for Potong Pasir to refine his terms to inquire into the adequacy and efficacy of CPIB's investigations. He has not done this. The Government cannot allow these doubts on the effectiveness of investigations of CPIB to stand unchallenged. Accordingly, before proceeding to investigate the terms of reference which the Member has spelt out, the Commission will first address itself to the first term of reference, and I read:

    '(1) To enquire whether -

    (a) the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau did all that was necessary to uncover all the acts of corruption or criminal wrongdoing of the late Mr Teh Cheang Wan in investigating complaints of or leads to acts of corruption by the late Mr Teh Cheang Wan as Minister for National Development;

    (b) the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau was thorough in their investigations before concluding that there was no involvement by any other Minister, Parliamentary Secretary, or Government officer in these acts of corruption or other criminal wrongdoing;

    (c) there has been any attempt to overlook, to conceal or to cover-up any information concerning corruption or criminal wrongdoing.'

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, it is in the public interest that there can be no suggestion of any concealment or cover- up of any corruption or criminal wrongdoing by the late Mr Teh Cheang Wan or any other Minister or Parliamentary Secretary or Government officer. Therefore, the thoroughness and effectiveness of investigations of the CPIB into the late Mr Teh Cheang Wan should be inquired into by the Commission of Inquiry. With regard to this term, the

Column: 1156

Deputy Public Prosecutor will lead evidence to show that CPIB carried out its duties effectively and properly. The Director of CPIB will give evidence under this term. After this term of reference has been addressed, the Commission will then address the terms requested by the Member for Potong Pasir. With regard to those terms, he will, as he had undertaken, bring forth his witnesses and lead in evidence.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Deputy Speaker, I must say that the Government do get things done very quickly. My final terms of reference, I believe, were given to the Minister not yesterday but on the 23rd March, and we have here before us the terms of reference in its proper form under the hand of the President. This is the first time I have seen these terms which include the first term of reference which I was unaware of. The reason why I wanted the Prime Minister to call for a public inquiry is because the former Minister has died and there is public interest on the matter. People are talking about it and it is only proper that the Government should let matters be open for the public to see and get their satisfaction, as I said, to the bottom of the matter.

    I have not for once accused the Government of cover- up and I hope the Minister will not bring to bear that I was casting any doubts or aspersions or innuendoes on the Government in regard to cover-up. We are also investigating whether or not the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau has done their job properly. I did not say they did not do their job properly. We have to go into that area which is quite separate. In fact, I think it is a completely different issue from what I originally had in mind. What I had in mind was only in matters related to the late Minister for National Development. But, nevertheless, since this has already been given under the hand of the President, I do not think we are in a position now to withdraw this first term of reference. That is in regard to the CPIB.

    Of course, we have got the terms of reference before us and I would certainly be writing to the Minister very soon in regard to what is known as the "getting up

Column: 1157

of the matter" which is no small matter, and the Prime Minister has already given his assurance that all files will be available, and not only available to me and my friends but also we have to go back again to have, maybe, a second look at the files. Also, we would require time to look into these files, adequate time. We do not want it to be a rush job. Certainly we would also require the Government to provide us with the details, maybe an officer of the Police or somebody who has got experience in investigative work with powers to subpoena for bank accounts of persons whom we would like to see. These are essential parts of investigative work.

    The other thing is, of course, lawyers are busy people and it is a practice that if their time is taken from their work to do this public service, I think they should be adequately remunerated. I believe there are provisions for this. Perhaps Members are unaware but there is already precedent set on this matter. Perhaps some of the first generation guards, the old guards in this House, will tell you that.

    Of course, the composition of the Commissioners has already been decided for us. We note that Mr Chan Sek Keong and two other lay members who are not connected with the Judiciary are acting as Commissioners. These are some of the matters we would be referring to in the letter that I will be sending to the Minister.

    The other thing is that it has been stressed that I will be leading evidence. Although the word used is that I will be leading evidence but it is not necessarily so that I shall always be at the stand. There will be other people who will also be leading evidence together with me. I must make that clear, it is not I alone, and for the next 10 days or 20 days, whatever it is, the time that is required in this public inquiry, I will be all the time at the stand. So I must make this clear - that there will be other people who will also be leading evidence.

    I would like to also make it clear to this House that if there are any matters which are necessary for us to get evidence, then I hope the Minister will make them available to us and there should be no quibbling as

Column: 1158

regards time or how we would like to view the files or whether or not we could go back again to view these files. Thank you, Sir.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, if I may touch on the points raised by the Member for Potong Pasir. He commented on the first term of reference. I have explained the reasons why this first term is necessary. I have referred to certain statements that he had made which to any reasonable person reading those statements must imply that the CPIB was less than thorough in its investigations. I am glad to hear him this morning that he did not intend to say that the CPIB did not investigate properly. But I take it that he does not object to this additional term because the Instrument of Appointment incorporates all that he wanted and the Commission's terms of reference will not exclude whatever he wanted. The Instrument includes his terms and more, which is necessary for the reasons I have given.

    Second, Sir, he has said that he will be writing to me with various requests. I think it is important to establish one point - that once the Commission of Inquiry has been established, it then is created and has its own life and momentum and the Executive does not interfere with the way the Commission of Inquiry goes about its business. What powers it has are spelt out in the Inquiry Commissions Act (Chapter 48). I will refer him to the provisions and he will note that the Commission has considerable powers of investigation, summoning of witnesses, production of documents, etc. So the requests which he envisages to direct at me, in fact, should be directed to the Secretary of the Commission and, when the Commission meets, to the Commissioners themselves, if he finds that his requests have not been adequately dealt with. That is an important point. We have established the Commission. It will be gazetted and thereafter it gets on with the job. The Executive, the Minister for Law, does not give special directions to the Commission and, indeed, it would be improper.

    He has said that he hopes that there will not be a rush job, that time will be required. I think this is understandable. Again, this will depend on the Commis-

Column: 1159

sion. There are certain preliminary matters which will have to be done. There will have to be an advertisement, a public advertisement calling for members of the public who have information or representations to make on any of the terms to submit their views within a specified time, and this will be done. I am sure the Commission will organize its sittings in such a way that all the preliminary work which has to be done and perhaps even requests by the Member for Potong Pasir for whatever information that he needs is obtained by him before they begin to sit. I assume that this will be so. As far as the Government is concerned, we also do not want this to be a rush job and the Commission should take its time with all the preliminary matters before they conduct their public sittings.

    He has asked for help by the Police. He hopes the Police will help us - by "us" I take it that he means the Commission of Inquiry. If he will look at the Instrument of Appointment, under the hand of the President, the last page, the Commissioner of Police is directed "to detail police officers to attend upon the Commission for the purpose of preserving order ..., to serve summonses ... perform such ... duties as the Commission may direct."

    Then he expressed the hope that the lawyers being busy people, those lawyers I take it from the private sector, I take it including himself, who will be involved in the Commission's proceedings, will be given adequate remuneration. Here, too, Sir, I would like to point out this is not something within my authority to decide. I will refer him to section 7(g) of the Inquiry Commissions Act where the Commissioners have the power to award any person who has attended any meeting of the Commissioners, including interpreters and so forth, such sums as in the opinion of the Commissioners may have been reasonably incurred by him by reason of such attendance. Of course, I do not know how the Commissioners will exercise their discretion. It is up to the Member for Potong Pasir to make a submission to the Commission and it is up to the Commission to exercise its discretion. I understand that in recent Commissions of Inquiry, like the Hotel New World, some of the people in the private sector who gave expert

Column: 1160

evidence and testimony did not claim any monetary compensation and, perhaps, their view was that they were doing a public service. But it is not for me to tell the Member and his colleagues from the legal profession who are going to help him, whether they should forgo this monetary compensation on a matter of such public interest which, he says, exists in this matter.

    Then he said in Parliament that although he has undertaken to lead evidence, he will not always be there - this is something we must leave to him - and that there will be others leading evidence, that he cannot be in the stand all the time. Well, I take it that if he leads evidence, he need not necessarily be in the stand. There is a difference between leading evidence and giving evidence. I am not sure whether there is a confusion here. We have understood him to say that on these terms, on his terms, he will lead in evidence and that he will bring others to give evidence. Quite frankly, I cannot see everybody wanting to lead evidence, but this must be something that we should have to leave to the Commission because, once the Commission is established, they are the masters of their procedure. But, no doubt, I am sure they will take note of the preamble paragraph in the Instrument which notes that the Member in this House had undertaken to lead in evidence. I think I have covered the points, Sir.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, this is an important document and, as I said, this is the first time I am seeing it this morning and there is a new term of reference and, of course, I am caught by surprise; an element of surprise is there. But, nevertheless, I will go along with it on this part of the evidence. But I suppose the Government will be leading evidence on the first reference. [Interruption] Yes.
